item.title: By: Open Minded Observer
item.dc:creator: Open Minded Observer
item.description:
I cannot count how many times I've had to explain to other White people that it's not our word to use or regulate. The most recent involved an incident between youth athletes. Another parent was expressing their dismay that "that kind of thing still happens in 2020." But, then they followed up with, "Some of the blame has to be placed on them for still using the word in their own community." I set aside the "us vs them" pretext because there just wasn't time to unpack that with a parent that had been pre-gaming in the parking lot. But, I did explain that it's not our word to use and it's not our word to regulate. I explained that there was a time when it was our word, when we invented it's meaning and used it as a weapon of oppression and because of that, we have forfeited any authority we have over it's continued usage.
I offer that story not looking for an "attaboy", but for any White folks passing through. That explanation cut through the willful ignorance. I think part of "well-meaning" White people's complex relationship with the word stems from the fact it serves as a reminder of atrocities that would be far more convenient for White folks to forget.
On an unrelated note: I still say, "Lemme show you somethin'" in fire marshal Bill's voice and had to dig up a video on You-Tube to explain it to my kids.
